title: Jean Dadario Burke
text:
Jean Dadario Burke is an American television <a href="soap%20opera">soap opera</a> <a href="Television%20producer">producer</a> and <a href="Television%20director">director</a>, most notably of the daytime television show "<a href="All%20My%20Children">All My Children</a>". During her career in daytime television, Burke won many <a href="Daytime%20Emmy%20Award">Daytime Emmy Award</a>s, primarily as executive producer for that show. She is credited with saving many characters from the canceled soap opera "<a href="Loving%20%28TV%20series%29">Loving</a>" and transporting them to its sequel show, "<a href="The%20City%20%281995%20TV%20series%29">The City</a>", by radically reworking the storyline, changing the setting to <a href="New%20York%20City">New York City</a>, eliminating half of the cast, and bringing in the star <a href="Morgan%20Fairchild">Morgan Fairchild</a>. She was part of a team that ultimately took the characters of "Loving" away from a "stilted upper-middle-class" orientation. She was instrumental in the careers of many daytime actors, including <a href="Josh%20Duhamel">Josh Duhamel</a>.
Burke was born in <a href="The%20Bronx">The Bronx</a>, and started her career as a production secretary on the show "<a href="Search%20for%20Tomorrow">Search for Tomorrow</a>". She held numerous jobs in the <a href="soap%20opera">soap opera</a> industry, doing casting, directing, and writing, and sometimes working on several shows concurrently. She was a casting assistant at "<a href="All%20My%20Children">All My Children</a>", was promoted to technical director, then later to director and senior producer, and finally to executive producer from 1998 to 2003. She was a director at "<a href="Another%20World%20%28TV%20series%29">Another World</a>" from 1988 to 1990. She was executive producer from 1995 to 1997 of the show "<a href="The%20City%20%281995%20TV%20series%29">The City</a>". From 1994 to 1995, she was executive producer of the daytime show "<a href="Loving%20%28TV%20series%29">Loving</a>". She was a director and associate producer of "<a href="Ryan%27s%20Hope">Ryan's Hope</a>" from 1988-1989.
